direction.raw_text: - AERIAL VIEW OF DOWNTOWN MANHATTAN - DAY MULTIPLE STREET SCENES - DAY The sidewalks crowded as usual.  A sea of humanity.  People come and go -- always in a hurry.  Oblivious of one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: being torn up by construction workers; A SANITATION TRUCK loading up refuse; VENDORS PEDDLING nuts and salted pretzels; PANHANDLERS blocking a passerby.  Intimidating.  Demanding.  Almost mocking. We're surrounded by the teeming life of the city as we've come to expect it -- complete with a cacophony of sound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: -- Phone kiosks and phone booths on the East Side and West Side -- uptown and down. One frustrated caller has lost his money in the slot and he takes it out on the equipment -- smashing the receiver violently against the coin box until the instrument splinters into a dozen pieces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are 237,911 pay telephones in the five burroughs of the city of New York.  Many of them are still in working order.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the phone in extreme close up.  We don't hear the words.  Only the facial expressions inform us that these are human beings under tremendous pressure.  Life in the city is wearing them down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S - JUST MOUTHS Lips jabbering into receivers.  Cross-cut against one another.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Despite increased usage of cellular devices, an estimated four and a half million New Yorkers and two million visitors still utilize pay telephones on a regular basis.  At thirty-five cents a pop... for the first three minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a phone booth situated on the southeast side of the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're looking at the telephone booth at the corner of 45th Street and 8th Avenue in the heart of the Manhattan theatrical district.  It has been scheduled to be removed and replaced by a kiosk.  It's one of the few remaining phone booths left in the city.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: on the irate caller in the booth -- a very well-dressed gray-haired lady -- totally conservative in appearance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have lied to me for the last time, you lowlife prick bastard!  I don't ever want to hear the sound of your fucking voice again. (listens) Yes, well fuck you, too! She slams down the receiver and exits.  The booth remains vacant for a brief interval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least three hundred calls daily originate from this booth.  The coins are collected twice a day. This booth has been burglarized forty-one times in the last six months. Someone is approaching the booth, fishing in his pocket for coins.  This is STUART SHEPARD, snappily dressed, his hair styled and his nails manicured.  Here is a man who clearly takes excellent care of himself.  He sports a Donna Karen suit and silk Armani tie. He's about to step into the booth when he's accosted by a middle-aged man in a soiled apron who's run out of a nearby restaurant and has finally caught up with him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stu, we got to talk.

direction.raw_text: Wish I could accommodate you, Mario, but this is my busy time of day.

direction.raw_text: How come you cross the street every time you go past the restaurant?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't I stop in later for some lunch?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's no more drinks or free meals until the restaurant starts showing up in the columns like you said.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm doing my level best for you people.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One lousy mention in the Post and you expect to eat for six months!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got the food critic from the Village Voice all lined up to give you a review.

direction.raw_text: That's what you tell me last July. And he never shows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was allowing you time to expand the menu.  Wallpaper the bathrooms, for God sakes.  You get only one shot with these fucking critics and I don't want you to blow a rare opportunity.

direction.raw_text: You the one blowing it.  How long you think you can fuck everybody?

direction.raw_text: Hold on right there.  I've got a very excellent reputation around this town.

direction.raw_text: Mister, you're nothing!

direction.raw_text: Believe me, Valerie's on the waiting list to audition.  Harry's got no complaints.  He just let me pick out this tie the other day.

direction.raw_text: That Harry's a damn fool!

direction.raw_text: Mario, please let me make this up to you.  How about I arrange for the opening night party for this new off-Broadway show I'm handling -- to be held at your place with local TV coverage on nine and eleven?  I mean I had it promised to another client -- who actually pays me money.  But it isn't firmed up yet.  And I could throw it your way.  Maybe.

direction.raw_text: What is involved?

direction.raw_text: You'd toss in the buffet for say seventy or eighty.  The producers would supply their own vino, of course.  I'd deliver you a truckload of celebrities.  And if they like the food, they'll all come back, naturally.

direction.raw_text: Is he still alive?

direction.raw_text: I saw him last night going into the Four Seasons.  I'll bring you over a whole VIP list when we come by for dinner.

direction.raw_text: How come everybody wants to eat but nobody wants to pay?

direction.raw_text: You can't think small like that. Hey, you still feature musicians Fridays and Saturdays?

direction.raw_text: At least they work for their meals.

direction.raw_text: What about Harry's daughter as an extra added attraction?  She'll belt out five or six showtunes -- two sets a night -- and it won't cost you a fucking nickel.

direction.raw_text: How come?

direction.raw_text: Star Showcase!  Let me handle setting that up.  And when she eventually goes on Letterman, she'll announce I'm currently appearing over at Mario's fine supper club.  Right over CBS she'll say that, Mario.

direction.raw_text: You're full of shit.  You know that?  All bullshit!

direction.raw_text: That's just a vulgar word for PR. (placing an arm around him) Mario, you can't hurt my feelings. Even when I was a kid and they hurled certain invectives my way, it never bothered me.  Other kids would fall apart if anybody called them a fucking name.  Me, I just loved the attention!  'Shit-for- brains' -- that's what the bigger kids named me.  And I answered to it.  Hey, 'shit-for brains' reporting for duty.  Everybody loved me for that.  I could take abuse.  After a while, I kind of wore them down.  There was nothing more they could say to me.  So they stopped.  I kind of missed it.

direction.raw_text: I'm sorry I even talked to you.

direction.raw_text: I'll bet your loving wife put you up to this.  She saw me pass by and she sent you out in the street. But I don't hold it against you personally -- you still serve up superior veal chop. (entering phone booth) Now I got urgent business to conduct, Mario. He slides the booth closed in Mario's face. The frustrated restaurateur glares at him through the glass before giving up and walking off -- talking to himself as he goes up the block.

direction.raw_text: Stu inserts his thirty-five cents and dials.

direction.raw_text: Hello, Mavis, sweet creature.

direction.raw_text: Good news in that arena.  Kelly goes into rehearsal as of Monday. You know how dedicated she is.  By the time she gets back from dancing her ass off, she goes right to sleep.  We'll have both our days and certain nights.  Not to mention when they take the show on the road.

direction.raw_text: How long is that for?

direction.raw_text: Sometimes I think if I have to give one more fucking manicure...

direction.raw_text: I never saw a worse set of nails. Bit right down to the quick.

direction.raw_text: I'm much better groomed since you've been looking after me.

direction.raw_text: I'm glad you admit it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Even Kelly remarked on it when I first met her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She could care less how you look. She's only interested in pushing her own career.  Some wife you're stuck with!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The marriage is not without its compensations.  Do you imagine I could afford that apartment on what I'm earning?  Not with everybody cutting back on the publicity.  Not to mention a million college graduates coming into the profession trying to cut me out. And one thing you can't expect from your clients is loyalty.  They get a couple of bad notices, they dump you.  Goodbye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't saying goodbye to you.  I was saying how the clients try to give you the wave off without even a month's notice. A conservative businessman now stands outside the booth waiting to use it.  He deliberately glances at his watch a few times to demonstrate his impatience.  This bothers Stu who slides the booth open a crack.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?  Is your watch busted?  It's twenty after eleven and I'm gonna be occupied indefinitely with my transaction.  So get out of my face! He closes the booth up again and turns his back to the gentleman who gives up and departs.

direction.raw_text: Sorry, honey.  There will be no further interruption.

direction.raw_text: Why must you always be calling me from some booth?

direction.raw_text: On account of that phone records are regularly subpoenaed in divorce proceedings.  And I don't want some entry showing up on my cellular bill either.  She gets the mail. She looks these items over. Sometimes she even dials up a strange number to see who it is.

direction.raw_text: Then she suspects something.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's only because her last husband, the choreographer, ran around on her.  She can't get that out of her head.  That's how she caught onto him.  The phone bills.

direction.raw_text: She hasn't developed much skill at holding a man.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know what a self-fulfilling prophecy is?  She was so sure I was going to find me a woman that she finally drove me back to you.  I thought I'd feel all guilty about it -- but I guess it hasn't kicked in yet. (beat) Still, I wouldn't do anything to hurt her.  Basically, Kelly's a decent individual.

direction.raw_text: What about hurting me?  Like last time?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hurt?  You were glad to be rid of me.

direction.raw_text: For a while I was, 'til I took stock of what was around.  You're the lesser of many evils.

direction.raw_text: I'll have it engraved.

direction.raw_text: Yeah, you're great enough looking to be mistaken for one of those thousand dollar a night girls.

direction.raw_text: Have a good day.  Make plenty of tips.  And leave the whole evening open.  She thinks I've got Knicks tickets. He hangs up.  Then whips a tiny cellular phone out of his jacket pocket, flips it open and dials.  Someone answers on the first ring.

direction.raw_text: I'll drop your item in sometime next week.  If you promise not to call me for a month. He hangs up.  Stu looks pleased as he folds the cell phone and tucks it away. Then he starts to vacate the booth.  The phone rings.  And rings.  Curious, he picks up the receiver.  There's a voice on the other end of the line.  A DISTINCTIVE MALE VOICE.

direction.raw_text: Jaundice they calls it.  Probably advanced liver trouble. (to Stu) If it's cirrhosis, you better find yourself a twelve step program and quick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks for your interest but I'm in perfect health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So how come his hand is shaking?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The man is cracking up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lookit the sweat pouring off the sonofabitch.  That's one sick mother you started up with, Leon!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me?  You're the one that brought me over and exposed me to all his germs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm terminal, okay?  Now can I close the booth and continue my conversation?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm worried now it might be catching.  All that money out of your sweaty pocket is probably crawling with some rare and incurable disease.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fine.  Give it back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What good's that?  We done touched it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well go wash your hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come on now.  Own up to what you're carrying.  Is it some of that sexually transmitted shit?  Cause in that case, we can relax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sick of you.  Now get out of my face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here we's being solicitous as to your health and you respond by heaping abuse!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whip his arrogant ass. Leon reaches into the booth and grabs Stu's jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Touch me and I'll throw up on you. At the suggestion, Leon lets go quickly. It looks like a stalemate.  Stu isn't vacating the booth and Leon and his lady are reluctant to touch him further.  He does indeed look sick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can see what I'm up against here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Want me to get rid of him for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you have in mind?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll think of something. Suddenly the red dot reappears on the forehead of the pimp. Leon doesn't realize it's there.  The hooker behind him has no way of seeing it.  But to Stu, there's no way to miss it. He reacts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God -- no. (into pay phone) Don't.  It's not necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You asked for my help.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll handle it myself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not doing too well.  I can settle it in a fraction of a second.  Shall I demonstrate?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. (to Leon) For your own safety, mister, just walk away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now the man is turning aggressive... issuing threats upon my person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're making this happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't hang up and step out, I'm about to topple this booth into the gutter with you inside it. Reluctant to touch Stu again, Leon assaults the booth itself. He begins shaking it violently -- trying to rip it from its foundation.  And the rickety booth is not too sturdy.  It starts rocking back and forth. Stu is thrown around inside it, barely keeping his footing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't my fault. (shouts) Stop that! But Leon continues rocking the booth.  It won't come loose -- so in frustration, he punches in a side pane of glass. The glass shatters all around Stu, who does his best to shield himself from the slivers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guy's insane!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only one way to stop a mad dog. Give me permission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If he forces you out of that booth, I've told you what to expect.  You or him, Stu. Leon is smashing other panes of glass now -- one after another -- as Stu cowers inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't cut yourself, honey. A crowd of derelicts and street people are now gathering to watch the out of control pimp take out his wrath on the booth and its occupant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Looks like the fucker is comin' loose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shove it out into the oncoming traffic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What'll you bet the bus could knock that fifty feet? The booth is being decimated but Stu hangs onto the phone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello?  Hello?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're breaking up.  We're about to be cut off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't help it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That counts as a hang-up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.  It can't.  That's not fair.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can still make him stop.  Say the word.  Can you hear me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Stu sees the red dot reappear on Leon's chest as he continues to barrage the booth with punches and kicks. Then Leon recoils, staggers a step backward.  He doesn't realize he's been shot. There's been no sound of gunfire.  Perhaps a silencer was used -- or the downtown traffic drowned out the solitary discharge. Leon looks confused at first.  His ladyfriend has no idea he's wounded -- neither do the derelicts and street people who've assembled on the corner. Even Stu isn't sure -- until the blood starts oozing from the wound on the pimp's chest -- staining his yellow vest. He isn't assaulting the booth anymore.  He's trying to keep his balance.  He slumps forward, hanging onto the booth for support -- only a few inches from Stu's face.  The blood runs down the side of the booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did it!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said 'yes.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said 'Yes, I can hear you.'  Not 'Yes -- kill the motherfucker!'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't try to renege on it.  I was following orders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're twisting it all around.  I didn't do this! Meanwhile, Leon leans upright against the booth.  Then his legs cave in and he begins to slide to his knees. Felicia runs up beside him.  She sees the blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I warned you not to cut yourself. (to crowd) Look at all that blood.  He must've hit an artery. She screams as Leon topples backwards onto the pavement.  Now his chest wound is evident.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Jesus.  What is that?  Talk to me!  What happened? The crowd tightens around the fallen body.  Street people who are fascinated but not shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Gunshot!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Sucking chest wound right over the heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Somebody call an ambulance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Call the meatwagon.  He's fucked up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You shut the fuck up! Her focus turns to Stu in the battered phone booth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you do that to him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I didn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You all saw it!  He shot my man without no provocation!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah.  Pumped one right into him at close range.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could I?  I don't even have a gun.  Look!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody get the fuck back!  They shoot one -- then they shoot everybody in sight!  Kill all the fucking witnesses! The crowd disperses to doorways and around the corner -- out of immediate range.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come back.  You've got to see -- I'm not armed. Only Felicia remains, leaning over the pimp's body, staring helplessly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hang up and dial 911.  Get a doctor!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't hang up.  That's what this is all about.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're gonna stand there and let him die?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can use this. (he dials) Emergency.  Yes.  There's been a shooting at Forty-fifth and Eighth -- on the corner.  A man is down. What's the difference who I am?  I don't want to be involved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's bullshit.  He's the shooter. You're talking to the shooter. Stu quickly disconnects the cellular.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That wasn't nice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go ahead -- make a fucking run for it.  I hope they gun you down -- like you did him!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not going anyplace.  I'm staying right here in this booth. (into pay phone) Unless you give me permission.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're attracting a lot of attention.  I suppose when the police get there, you'll accuse me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you expect me to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's up to you.  But any mention of me will not be appreciated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You mean...?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't even get to finish your sentence.  Oh look, that little red dot is dancing around all over you again.  You saw how quickly it can happen.  And how accurate I can be.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They can't blame me -- I'm not armed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's going to believe that?  With all those witnesses to the contrary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They can see with their own eyes. Not far away, we hear the BLAST of POLICE SIRENS drawing closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Remember to leave me out of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can I?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll put the proper spin on it. Isn't that your specialty?  Feeding the public a story that may not have a shred of truth -- and making it totally believable?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This isn't a story.  This is real. This is murder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you'd only dealt with the man reasonably, shown him some respect, this might not have been necessary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I gave him my money, my watch...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But not your respect.  Which is what he required of you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was a fucking thief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now he's a fucking dead thief. Do you feel better about that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't feel a bit guilty.  This is all your doing!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you're being disrespectful of me.  You never learn.  Your job is to deal with people -- but you're not good at it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hey, I'm not taking any more criticism from some lunatic sniper who gets his kicks killing strangers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You keep insisting I'm a stranger. Probably because you don't recognize the voice.  But there are cheap electronic devices available that disguise the voice.  I might not even be a man.  I might be one of those many women you've almost totally forgotten.  One who doesn't forgive easily.  One who wants to watch you squirm.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a man.  I know you're a man. Women don't kill with telescopic rifles.  They stab you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You sound so sure of that.  But you've never provoked any man as much as have the women in your life.  And so many of them, Stu. (a beat) Do you even remember their names?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got no time to rehash my whole life.  Oh my God!  The cops are here. Police cars are pulling up on all sides of Eighth Avenue. Traffic has suddenly been shut down.  Prowl cars have now blocked the streets.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : Everything is seen from Stu's perspective without intercuts. Half a dozen cops now emerge and approach with drawn guns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's him -- in the booth.  He's got a gun! As she hurls accusations, she's lugging Leon's lifeless body out into the gutter into the center of Eighth Avenue. It's a bright afternoon.  In the distance, we hear the maddening HONKING of uptown traffic that is now being rerouted, creating a huge bottleneck and raising the anger of irate motorists and bus drivers whose horns provide their simplest form of protest.  It's a discordant concert that echoes the confusion and frustration which Stu now feels... As the cops surround the booth -- at a distance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Throw down your weapon and come out with your hands raised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're ordering me to come out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see that.  Ignore them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What if they open fire?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They probably won't.  Look across on the east side of the street.  Do you see the tourist with the home video camera?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A distant crowd gathering on the opposite west side corner behind the police cars.  Some tourist is capturing the event on video.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's going to keep the police on their best behavior.  So long as you don't take what could be interpreted as hostile action, you'll be safe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You call this safe?  Six cops with guns pointed my way?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You want me to reduce them to three
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: or two?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Absolutely no more shooting.  Now is that clear?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can always change your mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know the drill.  Hands clasped behind the back of your neck -- moving slowly -- step out of the booth.  If we see any sign of a weapon, we will respond.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't, because there isn't any.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I repeat.  Raise your hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't.  I'm on a phone call. Now a black POLICE CAPTAIN arrives and takes full command of the situation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have thirty seconds to comply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I told you.  I'm busy.  Come back later.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Very good, Stu. The cops take cover behind parked cars, keeping Stu clearly in their sights.  He has no place to hide.  He's in the battered phone booth in plain view from all sides.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been given an order. The Sergeant slides up beside the Captain to confer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : We remain in LONG SHOT of the cops -- always from Stu's POV.  But we can hear their voices and all that is said as if they were in close up.  It has an odd, unreal and distancing effect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're dealing with a mental case. He's looking for us to kill him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well he's not getting his wish. In the center of the street, an ambulance pulls up and a team of medics jump out.  They rush to Leon's body.  (Again we hear their voices close, even though visually they are far off.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me he's gonna be alright.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Step aside.  Let us look at him. The medics push her aside -- then examine the victim.  He's
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing we can do.  Don't touch the body.  They'll need it to mark the crime scene. Far across the street, the Captain confers with his subordinates.  They are small figures on the screen but we hear them sharply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Same corner as two weeks ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe it's more than a coincidence. Cover me.  I need to talk to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've got your vest on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you think? The Captain steps out of cover and boldly approaches the phone booth.  He stops cautiously about fifteen feet away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not armed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Neither am I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah, sure.  I need to know what happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't talk about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sure you can.  My name's Ramey. Captain Ed Ramey.  What's yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look, I don't want to be friends.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look like you need a friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him you've already got a friend.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got a friend, okay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that who you're talking to on the phone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: None of your business.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When somebody gets shot, it becomes my business.  Let's not have anybody else killed.  I want to hear your side of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've got no side of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't worry, Stu.  I've got him fixed right in my sights.  I won't let him hurt you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has this happened to you before? The need to hurt someone?  To put a bullet in them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You won't believe anything I say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Try me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I couldn't shoot anybody.  I'm not armed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right.  I don't believe you. What's that bulge in your pants pocket?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That?  That's my cellular.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A cellular?  Then what are you doing in a phone booth making calls?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you want to see it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't reach for it, mister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then how can I show it to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't need to see it.  I know what's there.  All these witnesses saw you use it on him. From behind a parked car, a HOMELESS PERSON calls out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn straight! Another DERELICT, crouched in a doorway, joins in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yeah!  Shot him down like a dog!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're all lying.  Nobody saw it because it didn't happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A man is dead but it didn't happen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not on account of me!  This is like some bad dream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're walking through a bad dream and you can't wake up.  Do you want to wake up?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm trying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And in this dream, you killed that man.  He was bothering you so you iced him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then who did?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't tell him, Stu.  Or it'll be the last thing he ever hears.  His blood will be on your hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you saw it happen?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You were the closest one to him. You must've seen who did it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're trying to be honest with each other, aren't we?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not necessarily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm losing patience with this cop.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm handling this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who do you keep talking to on the phone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nobody.  My psychiatrist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excellent, Stu.  You're getting good at this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's this doctor's name?  It's important we know.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He says not to tell you.  It's privileged information.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damn good reply.  Now you're having fun.  Admit it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whatever you say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Playing it so close to the edge. I'll bet you've never felt so alive.  That's how I feel when I look through the sight and select somebody. The Captain begins advancing a few steps closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I respect your right to privacy. I've been to therapy myself.  The department provides it.  I know it's not good form for a cop to be admitting that, but...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him not to come any closer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stop right there.  Back up a few steps.  Back where you were.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If it makes you more comfortable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell him to read you your rights.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I want you to read me my rights and stop asking questions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Al least tell me your first name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's my right not to have any name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No gun and no name.  You're a highly underprivileged person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Demand a lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And get me a lawyer, too.  I want a lawyer brought down here to negotiate my surrender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brilliant, Stu.  Keep winging it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be hard to find a lawyer willing to risk his life.  But if you hand over the gun...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can I when you won't let me take it out?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll take it out for you -- as soon as you exit the booth with your hands raised and...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now we're back to that again.  It's always "Get out of the booth.' 'You can't stay in the booth.' Well, I like it in the fucking booth.  It's my whole world now. It's my booth and I'm never coming out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're not about to force you because there could be a miscalculation and then we'd never find out why this happened.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why is it so important to know? The guy is dead.  Isn't that enough?  Knowing isn't going to make him alive again.  So who gives a fuck!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's what makes the job interesting.  Finding out why. Something drove you to do this. You didn't go out today expecting this to happen.  It was a nice day. You were out for a walk.  And then suddenly it all changed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All I wanted was to make a phone call.  One lousy phone call for thirty-five fucking cents.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Careful, Stu.  Don't volunteer too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You got some bad news on that call.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The worst.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something that pushed you over the edge?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I've been falling ever since.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Time to land.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When you hit bottom, you die.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm your safety net.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I tell you what you want to know
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: you'll die, too. Something about the implied threat sends a chill through Captain Ramey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Captain's head as seen through a telescopic sight. Ramey could be dead in an instant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: : The only time we deviate from Stu's perspective is when we see the sniper's POV through his scope.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: BACK ON STU IN THE BOOTH, the detective fifteen feet away. Ramey decides to back off momentarily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll go see about that lawyer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now that's a good idea. The Captain withdraws back across the street.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's lucky.  I had him centered in my cross hairs.  I really had to restrain myself. We hear the approach of a helicopter. Stu peers up ward as not one but two choppers appear above the tall buildings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not the police.  It's the media.  You're news, Stuart. The helicopters circle above.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've never gotten this much press for any of your clients.  I'm making you a famous person.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're just hoping for coverage of me dying in the gutter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their presence is putting the police on their continued best behavior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Those cops are just looking for any excuse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then don't give them one. Then, as if on cue, Stu's cellular phone in his pocket starts ringing. But he can't allows himself to reach for it.  To do so might cause the police to believe he was trying to draw his gun. It rings quietly -- virtually inaudible outside the booth. Drowned out by the traffic horns, the static from the police radios and the newly introduced sound of television helicopters circling over Eighth Avenue taking video coverage of the event below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who could it be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Kelly.  She was worried about me. Stu is afraid to reach in his pocket lest the cops think he's going for a gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maybe she's seen this on television.  It must be on every channel by now.  Breaking news.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She doesn't watch daytime TV.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One of the neighbors could've alerted her. The cell phone keeps ringing, almost drowned out by the sound of helicopters circling overhead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you saying this?  You want me to reach in my pocket so you can see them open fire?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's an unwarranted accusation and very unbecoming in light of the good advice I've given in the past. Have I ever steered you wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God -- how I'd love to hear her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It might even be worth it.  She's insistent, isn't she? The cellular won't stop ringing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If she knows I'm in trouble, she won't give up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The space between the roof of the booth and the sheets of clouded plastic.  We see the fluorescent lighting fixture covered with dust.  The solitary object -- a cruel-looking weapon. Now Stu's fingertips protrude into the small space.  He touches the gun, brushes back and forth, feeling the roughness of the grip.

direction.raw_text: as below he continues to hesitate -- it's agony -- The sweat pours down his forehead and his eyes are squeezed tightly shut.  He can already imagine the police bullets tearing into him.

Not at the police, but at the high rise buildings across the street. At the thousands of windows that look down upon him. He gets off two shots before a solitary rifle shot rings out in response.

direction.raw_text: He has fired.
